title: Another question example
content:
What is the output of this code?

```javascript
console.log(typeof null);
```
explanation: The typeof operator returns 'object' for null, which is a known quirk in JavaScript. This is considered a bug in the language that cannot be fixed due to backward compatibility.

title: Open-ended question example
content: Explain the concept of closures in JavaScript and provide a practical example.
explanation: Closures allow functions to access variables from their outer scope even after the outer function has returned. This is a fundamental concept in JavaScript.
sampleAnswers: A closure is a function that has access to variables in its outer scope even after the outer function has returned. Example: function outer(x) { return function inner(y) { return x + y; }; }
Closures are created when a function is defined inside another function and has access to the outer function's variables. They're commonly used for data privacy and creating factory functions.

title: True/False question example
content: In JavaScript, all variables declared with 'var' are hoisted to the top of their scope.
explanation: True. Variables declared with 'var' are hoisted to the top of their scope and initialized with 'undefined' before the code execution.

title: Advanced code question example
content: Implement a debounce function that accepts a function and a delay, and returns a debounced version of the function.
explanation: A debounce function delays the execution of a function until after a specified time has passed since it was last invoked. This is useful for optimizing performance in scenarios like search inputs or window resize events.

testCases.description: Should return a function that delays execution

sampleAnswers: function debounce(func, delay) { let timeoutId; return function(...args) { clearTimeout(timeoutId); timeoutId = setTimeout(() => func.apply(this, args), delay); }; }
